TableContextTimeStampAfterTable: {6543=Upon release in 1969, it met with slower sales than his previous albums, as pop audiences struggled to keep pace with Walker's increasingly experimental approach. The dense lush string arrangements by Wally Stott seemed to evoke a Vegas-style lounge crooner atmosphere, but one tinted with surreal drones and touches of dissonance., 7624=A cover of "30 Century Man" by the Jigsaw Seen was used in the animated film Futurama: Bender's Big Score. Marc Almond covered the song "Big Louise" in 1982 with his band Marc and the Mambas on the album Untitled., 7039=Since its release, it has been regarded by many of Walker's fans as a favourite. The title of the compilation Fire Escape in the Sky: The Godlike Genius of Scott Walker is taken from the lyrics of the song "Big Louise", and the 2006 documentary Scott Walker: 30 Century Man is named after "30 Century Man".}
textBeforeTable: Release history[edit] Peter Knight - Arranged and conducted "Funeral Tango" Wally Stott - Arranged and conducted all songs except "30 Century Man" and "Funeral Tango" Scott Walker - vocals, arranger Personnel[edit] The original U.S. Smash label vinyl issue omitted "30 Century Man", replacing it with "Lights of Cincinnati", a UK non-LP single from the same period. This issue also featured a different cover design from the UK Philips release. 4:57 Brel, Rod McKuen "If You Go Away"   13. 2:56 Jouannest, Brel, Shuman "Funeral Tango"   12. 3:45 Gérard Jouannest, Jacques Brel, Mort Shuman "Sons Of"   11. 2:48   "Two Weeks Since You've Gone"   10.
